docs.lead_paragraph: Saying New Jersey's sustained economic boom and the state's mounting surpluses had created an ''unprecedented opportunity,'' Gov. Christine Todd Whitman proposed today her most generous budget yet, a $21.2 billion plan that increases spending by $1.3 billion for a host of new programs, tax cuts and ambitious school and highway construction projects. Mrs. Whitman, a Republican, asserted that her spending plan, which she titled a Prosperity Dividend, would actually strengthen her record as a fiscal conservative. She boasted that she had completely eliminated so-called one-shot revenues and that her budget would leave yet another record surplus while keeping the average yearly growth in spending during her two terms to the lowest level of any governor in 30 years.

headline.main: Budget Rise Is Proposed By Whitman

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman, saying New Jersey's sustained economic boom and state's mounting surpluses has created an 'unprecedented opportunity,' proposes her most generous budget yet, $21.2 billion plan that increases spending by $1.3 billion for host of new programs, tax cuts and ambitious school and highway construction projects; Whitman also proposes two-year suspension of employees' contribution to unemployment insurance; other proposals outlined (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a large dose of unreality to the presidential debates from the start. Each of the major candidates proposed paying for initiatives by tapping surpluses that were more speculative than real. True, the Congressional Budget Office had told them that the federal surplus, outside the Social Security program, would equal about $1 trillion over the next 10 years. But that estimate was based on a highly debatable assumption -- that Congress would adhere to onerous spending caps it set in 1997 to achieve a balanced budget. Those caps were broken open this year, a measure of the difficulty in meeting them. If scrupulously observed the next two years, the caps would require Congress to cut non-military discretionary programs by an astonishing 30 percent and then maintain the programs at that level for the next decade. Virtually no one expects Congress to inflict that much pain. Under the more reasonable assumption that Congress keeps current programs intact, there will be no federal surplus. Yet Bill Bradley said that future surpluses would pay for his $650 billion, 10-year program of universal health insurance. George W. Bush's plan would cut taxes by more than $1 trillion, courtesy of the surplus. Even the fiscal moderates, Al Gore and John McCain, proposed paying for slimmed-down versions of their opponents' plans with future surpluses.

headline.main: Editorial Observer; What Happens if the Budget Surplus Is Real?

docs.abstract: Michael Weinstein's Editorial Observer column on proposals by presidential candidates on ways to spend budget surplus; notes surplus is more speculative than real since it is based on assumption that Congress will adhere to onerous spending caps set in 1997 to achieve balanced budget; says under reasonable assumptions that Congress will keep current programs intact, there will be no surplus (M)
docs.snippet: There has been a large dose of unreality to the presidential debates from the start. Each of the major candidates proposed paying for initiatives by tapping surpluses that were more speculative than real. True, the Congressional Budget Office had...

docs.lead_paragraph: In the long run, the most important consequence of the Iowa presidential caucuses this year may be the impression they leave of Gov. George W. Bush on voters across the nation. In the process of achieving a solid victory, has he lost a bit of his aura as a man planted squarely in the center? His entire candidacy has been predicated on the determination of many Republicans, chafing after eight years of Democratic control of the White House, to put party unity and solidarity ahead of ideology. That priority gave Mr. Bush early fund-raising success and leadership backing.
docs.abstract: News analysis of solid victory by Republican presidential candidate Gov George W Bush in Iowa caucuses; Bush may have lost bit of aura as man planted squarely in center since Iowa campaign forced him to speak more specifically than he had hoped on major issues, such as abortion (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: '' 'Harry and Louise' Return, With Health Insurance Plan'' (news article, Jan. 19): Harry and Louise were featured in the insurance industry television commercials that defeated the Clinton universal health plan. This time the insurance industry wants the government to subsidize private health insurance for the millions of people without insurance. Insurance executives say most of the money would be passed on to the doctors, hospitals and others that provide health care. Look at the track record of this industry over the last 10 years.
docs.abstract: Letter from Dr Melvin H Kirschner, commenting on return of 'Harry and Louise' commercials, calls for single-payer system as way to stop wasting patient-care money on marketing and obscene executive incomes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Daniel L. Teafatiller, a rancher, sold all his cattle, except his two prize bulls, which he asked his son-in-law to look after while he is away. Patrick F. Martin, an account manager for Microsoft, is trying not to think about the six-figure stock bonus he will miss when he is gone. Ron De La Rosa, a lawyer with his own practice down by the courthouse here, is scrambling to try or settle as many cases as possible. ''I've got a murder the judge wants me to finish before I go,'' he said the other day in his office.

headline.main: New Role of Guard Transforming Military

docs.abstract: Special report, Changing the Guard, finds Pentagon is relying more heavily on National Guard and Reserves to ease strain, with overseas operations proliferating and armed services having shrunk by one-third since end of cold war; Guard and Reserves, formerly place for conscripts seeking to avoid real active duty while earning extra cash or college tuition, have become essential to American military operations worldwide with members outnumbering those in regular force, 564,000 to 479,000; reservists spent less than one million days on active duty supporting military operations in late 1980's, compared with nearly 13 million in 1999; greater demand has raised questions over whether part-time units are ready for missions important to national security; has tested Pentagon's desire to better mix active-duty and reserve units, particularly in Army, where old internecine rivalries simmer; biggest impact is at home, where deployments have forced so-called 'weekend warriors' to juggle civilian lives and military service; while reservists are used to being away for two weeks of drilling per year, longer tours mean disrupting families and putting careers or college on hold; deployment of 49th Armored Division in Texas to Bosnia as part of NATO's force discussed; photos; graphs (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, Al Gore was suffering the tortures of the media-damned. The vice president was derided for running a Washington-based campaign with a sclerotic staff. He was falling behind in fund-raising. He was seen by even his knee-jerk union supporters as the Ultimate Stiff. He was overpaying media advisers to give him an earth-tone transplant to turn him into an Alpha Male.
docs.abstract: William Safire Op-Ed column offers Democratic presidential candidate Bill Bradley advice on how to wage more effective campaign against rival, Vice Pres Al Gore (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As he commented on the end of his seventh year in office last week, President Clinton professed to be ''feeling good and grateful'' about his time in the White House, and he spoke about his eagerness ''to milk every last moment of every day.'' For all that, 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue seems to radiate an aura of isolation and missed opportunities these days. Presidential friends speak of his ''lonely voice'' on the telephone. Mr. Clinton's two closest political associates -- Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton -- do not want him hovering as they launch their new careers. The image of a home-alone presidency was reinforced when Mr. Clinton was asked if he felt mournful about starting his final year in the White House. ''When I go in a room in the White House now I look around more carefully to make sure . . . that I've actually noticed something that I may not have seen.'' He added, ''I wish I didn't have to sleep at all for a year.'' Like all retiring presidents, Mr. Clinton will experience a cruelly abrupt loss of power at this time next year. But the winding down of this presidency -- a 12-month process that began Thursday -- has its own special poignancy. Mr. Clinton entered office on a wave of generational optimism that was tamped down by incrementalism, triangulation, partisanship and the devastating X-factor of his own indiscipline. Nothing he said in his first Inaugural Address about breaking the hold of special interests in Washington will be quoted as often as ''I did not have sexual relations with that woman, Miss Lewinsky.'' Friends and political allies speak with increasing openness about how he disappointed them. Historians are beginning to categorize Mr. Clinton as a politician of splendid natural talent and some significant accomplishments who nonetheless missed the greatness that once seemed within his grasp. All this contributes to the wistful aura at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue and to the president's obsessive determination to continue work on his legacy.
docs.abstract: Editorial, commenting on Pres Clinton's final year in office, says White House seems to radiate aura of isolation and missed opportunities; says Clinton seems to have no guaranteed hold on affections of American people, failing to establish trademark leadership style (M).

docs.lead_paragraph: After I expressed my intent to explore an area that strikes terror of embarrassment into so many hearts, a colleague warned, ''I wouldn't go there if I were you.'' Linguistic exploration rejects such faintheartedness. We will now deal forthrightly with the cliche that has been embraced by the squirming squeamish: Don't go there.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 1-23-00: On Language; Don't Go There

docs.abstract: William Safire, in his On Language column, discusses expression 'Don't go there'; comments on name of acting Russian president, Vladimir Putin; comments on euphemism 'mental-health consumer,' to refer to mental patients (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Massachusetts lawmakers returned to work this month, these jumbo-sized, hard-to-chew items were on their legislative plate: the financial meltdown of the state's biggest health maintenance organization, Harvard Pilgrim Health Care; rising prices for prescription drugs, and the lack of an H.M.O. patients' bill of rights. And more: the confidentiality of medical records; prompter payment by insurers; long-term care; nursing salaries, and on and on, for at least 400 bills related to health care.

headline.main: FOR MANY STATES, HEALTH CARE BILLS ARE TOP PRIORITY

docs.abstract: National Conference of State Legislatures reports health care issues accounted for greater proportion of bills in state legislatures nationwide, about 27,000 out of 140,000 bills, than any other issue in 1999; 1,400 bills became law and 1999; 16,000 proposals have carried over and have been introduced for 2000, although fewer state legislatures are in session; conference director Lee Dixon predicts states will continue to enact legislation that addresses concerns of citizens regarding access to care, managed care and cost of care; other officials comment (M)
